    Basic properties of the manifold Fr√©chet derivative #

    In this file, we show various properties of the manifold Fr√©chet derivative, mimicking the API for Fr√©chet derivatives.

    • basic properties of unique differentiability sets
    • various general lemmas about the manifold Fr√©chet derivative
    • deducing differentiability from smoothness,
    • deriving continuity from differentiability on manifolds,
    • congruence lemmas for derivatives on manifolds
    • composition lemmas and the chain rule

    Unique differentiability sets in manifolds #

    theorem mdifferentiableOn_iff_of_subset_source {ùïú : Type u_1} [NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {E : Type u_2} [NormedAddCommGroup E] [NormedSpace ùïú E] {H : Type u_3} [TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ùïú E H} {M : Type u_4} [TopologicalSpace M] [ChartedSpace H M] {E' : Type u_5} [NormedAddCommGroup E'] [NormedSpace ùïú E'] {H' : Type u_6} [TopologicalSpace H'] {I' : ModelWithCorners ùïú E' H'} {M' : Type u_7} [TopologicalSpace M'] [ChartedSpace H' M'] {f : M ‚Üí M'} {s : Set M} [IsManifold I 1 M] [IsManifold I' 1 M'] {x : M} {y : M'} (hs : s ‚äÜ (chartAt H x).source) (h2s : Set.MapsTo f s (chartAt H' y).source) :
    MDifferentiableOn I I' f s ‚Üî ContinuousOn f s ‚àß DifferentiableOn ùïú (‚Üë(extChartAt I' y) ‚àò f ‚àò ‚Üë(extChartAt I x).symm) (‚Üë(extChartAt I x) '' s)

    If the set where you want f to be smooth lies entirely in a single chart, and f maps it into a single chart, the smoothness of f on that set can be expressed by purely looking in these charts.
